clusters.title: Ceasefire talks between Israel and Hamas begin as White House says it wants to ‘move very quickly’ – Middle East crisis live
clusters.neutral_headline: Israel and Hamas Begin Indirect Talks Regarding Ceasefire

items.title: Ceasefire talks between Israel and Hamas begin as White House says it wants to ‘move very quickly’ – Middle East crisis live
items.standfirst: Delegations from Israel and Hamas began indirect negotiations; Trump press secretary says US president wants hostages to be released ‘as soon as possible’Iran signalled its support for Trump’s Gaza plan, with the country’s foreign ministry saying it supports any initiative that brings an end to the genocide of Palestinian people.Iran’s foreign ministry wrote in a post on X:Taking into account the dangerous dimensions and aspects of this proposal, and while reiterating its warning about the repeated breaches and obstructionism by the Zionist regime in fulfilling its promises, especially in light of its expansionist and racist plans, the Islamic Republic of Iran considers any decision in this regard to be within the authority of the Palestinian people and resistance.It welcomes any decision by them that guarantees halting the genocide of Palestinians, the withdrawal of the occupying Zionist army from Gaza, respect for the Palestinian people’s right to self-determination, the entry of humanitarian aid, and the reconstruction of Gaza. Continue reading...
items.content: Delegations from Israel and Hamas began indirect negotiations; Trump press secretary says US president wants hostages to be released ‘as soon as possible’Iran signalled its support for Trump’s Gaza plan, with the country’s foreign ministry saying it supports any initiative that brings an end to the genocide of Palestinian people.Iran’s foreign ministry wrote in a post on X:Taking into account the dangerous dimensions and aspects of this proposal, and while reiterating its warning about the repeated breaches and obstructionism by the Zionist regime in fulfilling its promises, especially in light of its expansionist and racist plans, the Islamic Republic of Iran considers any decision in this regard to be within the authority of the Palestinian people and resistance.It welcomes any decision by them that guarantees halting the genocide of Palestinians, the withdrawal of the occupying Zionist army from Gaza, respect for the Palestinian people’s right to self-determination, the entry of humanitarian aid, and the reconstruction of Gaza. Continue reading...

items.title: Israel and Hamas meet on hostages, Trump’s plan

Hamas accepted the general terms of the plan on Friday, including the release of all remaining hostages, living and dead. Israeli…

items.title: Israel and Hamas begin indirect talks as hopes rise of ending Gaza war
items.standfirst: Hamas’s acceptance of key conditions of deal galvanises momentum but large gaps remain between campsGaza ceasefire talks – live updatesIsrael and Hamas have begun indirect talks in Egypt on a US ceasefire proposal amid cautious optimism that the nearly two-year war in Gaza may be nearing its end, despite deep divisions between the two sides.Negotiations will focus on the release of hostages held by Hamas in exchange for Palestinian prisoners in Israeli jails, as well as the partial withdrawal of Israeli troops from Gaza. The three issues constitute the first phase of a 20-point plan presented by the US president, Donald Trump, last week that aims to end the war. Continue reading...
items.content: Hamas’s acceptance of key conditions of deal galvanises momentum but large gaps remain between campsGaza ceasefire talks – live updatesIsrael and Hamas have begun indirect talks in Egypt on a US ceasefire proposal amid cautious optimism that the nearly two-year war in Gaza may be nearing its end, despite deep divisions between the two sides.Negotiations will focus on the release of hostages held by Hamas in exchange for Palestinian prisoners in Israeli jails, as well as the partial withdrawal of Israeli troops from Gaza. The three issues constitute the first phase of a 20-point plan presented by the US president, Donald Trump, last week that aims to end the war. Continue reading...

items.title: Trump urges negotiators to ‘move fast’ as Gaza ceasefire talks set to begin in Egypt
items.standfirst: Talks on Monday expected to focus on release of hostages and end to war, after Israel kills 63 people in Gaza in past dayDonald Trump has urged negotiators to “move fast” in talks focused on the release of hostages held by Hamas in Gaza and a broader end to the war, as representatives arrived in Egypt for discussions set to begin on Monday.The talks will focus on the first phase of Trump’s plan to end the war in Gaza, the Egyptian foreign ministry said, which is the release of the remaining 48 hostages held by Hamas in return for Palestinian prisoners held in Israel. Continue reading...
items.content: Talks on Monday expected to focus on release of hostages and end to war, after Israel kills 63 people in Gaza in past dayDonald Trump has urged negotiators to “move fast” in talks focused on the release of hostages held by Hamas in Gaza and a broader end to the war, as representatives arrived in Egypt for discussions set to begin on Monday.The talks will focus on the first phase of Trump’s plan to end the war in Gaza, the Egyptian foreign ministry said, which is the release of the remaining 48 hostages held by Hamas in return for Palestinian prisoners held in Israel. Continue reading...

Hamas accepted the general terms of a plan, including the release of hostages.
Iran supports any initiative that ends the "genocide of Palestinians" in Gaza.
Iran considers decisions regarding Gaza within the authority of Palestinians.

clusters.title: A mess of Macron's making? France in crisis as latest government falls in 14 hours
clusters.neutral_headline: France Faces Political Crisis After Prime Minister Resigns

items.title: A mess of Macron's making? France in crisis as latest government falls in 14 hours
items.standfirst: Emmanuel Macron losing his third prime minister, in the 16 months since he dissolved parliament and lost ensuing snap elections. Sebastien Lecornu breaking a Fifth Republic record by lasting just 27 days as head of government.
items.content: Emmanuel Macron losing his third prime minister, in the 16 months since he dissolved parliament and lost ensuing snap elections. Sebastien Lecornu breaking a Fifth Republic record by lasting just 27 days as head of government.

items.title: France in fresh political and market turmoil after prime minister resigns
items.standfirst: Sébastien Lecornu, who quit on Monday, is asked by Emmanuel Macron to quickly negotiate a stability plan
items.content: Sébastien Lecornu, who quit on Monday, is asked by Emmanuel Macron to quickly negotiate a stability plan

items.title: France in fresh political crisis as PM Lecornu quits after 26 days
items.standfirst: Lecornu was asked by President Macron to stay on until Wednesday in a last-ditch attempt to achieve "stability" for the country.
items.content: Lecornu was asked by President Macron to stay on until Wednesday in a last-ditch attempt to achieve "stability" for the country.

items.title: France is in crisis but bond markets leave other governments at risk of meltdown too
items.standfirst: Investors rattled by resignation of French PM but country is not alone in trying to grapple with political mathsMacron asks outgoing French PM to make last-ditch effort to avoid political crisisWhat happened on a chaotic day in French politics – and what next?Sébastien Lecornu’s abrupt resignation as the French prime minister on Monday after less than a month in the role marked the latest clash between France’s stretched public finances and its polarised politics.Lecornu was the latest prime minister to try and fail to cobble together a package of spending cuts and tax rises that would pass muster in a parliament without a clear majority, and contain mounting bond market pressures. Continue reading...
items.content: Investors rattled by resignation of French PM but country is not alone in trying to grapple with political mathsMacron asks outgoing French PM to make last-ditch effort to avoid political crisisWhat happened on a chaotic day in French politics – and what next?Sébastien Lecornu’s abrupt resignation as the French prime minister on Monday after less than a month in the role marked the latest clash between France’s stretched public finances and its polarised politics.Lecornu was the latest prime minister to try and fail to cobble together a package of spending cuts and tax rises that would pass muster in a parliament without a clear majority, and contain mounting bond market pressures. Continue reading...

items.title: France's President Macron gives outgoing PM Lecornu one last chance
items.standfirst: France's new prime minister resigned on Monday after less than a month in office, sinking the country further into a political crisis and piling pressure on President Emmanuel Macron to find a way out of the deadlock. As a response, the President asked outgoing PM Lecornu to hold 'final talks' and attempt to solve the situation by Wednesday. Story by Marc Perelman.
items.content: France's new prime minister resigned on Monday after less than a month in office, sinking the country further into a political crisis and piling pressure on President Emmanuel Macron to find a way out of the deadlock. As a response, the President asked outgoing PM Lecornu to hold 'final talks' and attempt to solve the situation by Wednesday. Story by Marc Perelman.

items.title: France's Macron tasks outgoing PM Lecornu to hold final talks to stabilize country
items.standfirst: French President Emmanuel Macron has asked outgoing Prime Minister Sebastien Lecornu to hold final talks by Wednesday evening with political parties to stabilise the country, Macron's office said on Monday. Earlier on Monday, Lecornu offered his and his newly formed government's resignation after allies and foes alike had threatened to topple the government. Deatails by FRANCE 24 reporter Clovis Casali.
items.content: French President Emmanuel Macron has asked outgoing Prime Minister Sebastien Lecornu to hold final talks by Wednesday evening with political parties to stabilise the country, Macron's office said on Monday. Earlier on Monday, Lecornu offered his and his newly formed government's resignation after allies and foes alike had threatened to topple the government. Deatails by FRANCE 24 reporter Clovis Casali.

items.title: Macron asks outgoing French PM to make last-ditch effort to resolve political crisis
items.standfirst: French president requests Sébastien Lecornu stay on for 48 hours after he quit complaining of ‘egos’Explainer: What happened on a chaotic day in French politics – and what could happen next?Hours after France’s new prime minister resigned less than a month after he was appointed, Emmanuel Macron has asked him to stay on for two more days in a last-ditch effort to chart a way out of the country’s rapidly deepening political crisis.The French president on Monday evening gave Sébastien Lecornu – who had earlier become the third prime minister of the EU’s second-biggest economy to quit within a year – 48 hours to “conduct final negotiations … to define a platform for action and stability”. Continue reading...
items.content: French president requests Sébastien Lecornu stay on for 48 hours after he quit complaining of ‘egos’Explainer: What happened on a chaotic day in French politics – and what could happen next?Hours after France’s new prime minister resigned less than a month after he was appointed, Emmanuel Macron has asked him to stay on for two more days in a last-ditch effort to chart a way out of the country’s rapidly deepening political crisis.The French president on Monday evening gave Sébastien Lecornu – who had earlier become the third prime minister of the EU’s second-biggest economy to quit within a year – 48 hours to “conduct final negotiations … to define a platform for action and stability”. Continue reading...

items.title: France: President Macron under pressure after fifth PM in two years resigns
items.standfirst: Prime minister Sébastien Lecornu has resigned, creating a political earthquake in France. Lecornu was Prime minister for under a month, and was the fifth to hold the post in two years. His resignation renewed the focus on France's President, Emmanuel Macron, who is under pressure to act to resolve the crisis, by either dissolving the National Assembly, like he did last year, or quitting himself. Story by Charlotte Lam and France 2.
items.content: Prime minister Sébastien Lecornu has resigned, creating a political earthquake in France. Lecornu was Prime minister for under a month, and was the fifth to hold the post in two years. His resignation renewed the focus on France's President, Emmanuel Macron, who is under pressure to act to resolve the crisis, by either dissolving the National Assembly, like he did last year, or quitting himself. Story by Charlotte Lam and France 2.

items.title: France's Socialist Party does not reach out to hard-left as political crisis deepens
items.standfirst: France’s Socialist party has called on President Emmanuel Macron to appoint a new PM from the left bloc. But a senior Socialist party official did not mention the hard-left France Unbowed party, notes FRANCE 24’s Claire Paccalin, reporting from outside Socialist Party headquarters. “We are seeing the contours of an emergence of a new alliance on the left, but one that does not include the far-left,” said Paccalin.
items.content: France’s Socialist party has called on President Emmanuel Macron to appoint a new PM from the left bloc. But a senior Socialist party official did not mention the hard-left France Unbowed party, notes FRANCE 24’s Claire Paccalin, reporting from outside Socialist Party headquarters. “We are seeing the contours of an emergence of a new alliance on the left, but one that does not include the far-left,” said Paccalin.

items.title: France: Socialist Party says is not calling for a snap election after the PM resigns
items.standfirst: France's new Prime Minister Sebastien Lecornu and his government resigned on Monday, hours after Lecornu announced his cabinet line-up, making it the shortest-lived administration in modern French history and deepening the country's political crisis. The unexpected resignation came after allies and foes alike threatened to topple the new government, which Lecornu said meant he could not do his job. The Socialist Party reacted reacted to his announcement, saying it was calling for the dissolution of Parliament nor the resignation of President Macron. Analysis by FRANCE 24 international affairs editor Angela Diffley.
items.content: France's new Prime Minister Sebastien Lecornu and his government resigned on Monday, hours after Lecornu announced his cabinet line-up, making it the shortest-lived administration in modern French history and deepening the country's political crisis. The unexpected resignation came after allies and foes alike threatened to topple the new government, which Lecornu said meant he could not do his job. The Socialist Party reacted reacted to his announcement, saying it was calling for the dissolution of Parliament nor the resignation of President Macron. Analysis by FRANCE 24 international affairs editor Angela Diffley.

items.title: French premier resigns hours after naming government, plunging France further into political chaos
items.standfirst: France’s new Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu resigned less than a month in office and less than 24 hours after naming a new government that prompted a key coalition ally to withdraw support. The move plunged the country into a deep political crisis and left French President Emmanuel Macron with few options. Story by Carys Garland.
items.content: France’s new Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu resigned less than a month in office and less than 24 hours after naming a new government that prompted a key coalition ally to withdraw support. The move plunged the country into a deep political crisis and left French President Emmanuel Macron with few options. Story by Carys Garland.

items.title: Macron under pressure to call parliamentary elections after French PM quits
items.standfirst: Sebastien Lecornu's resignation has come kind of completely out of the blue - and there doesn't seem to be an obvious reason for it.
items.content: Sebastien Lecornu's resignation has come kind of completely out of the blue - and there doesn't seem to be an obvious reason for it.

items.title: Could France's next Prime minister be a socialist?
items.standfirst: France’s new prime minister Sébastien Lecornu resigned less than 24 hours after naming his government and after less than a month in office, plunging the country into a deep political crisis and leaving French President Emmanuel Macron with few options. Details by FRANCE 24 Reporter Claire Paccalin.
items.content: France’s new prime minister Sébastien Lecornu resigned less than 24 hours after naming his government and after less than a month in office, plunging the country into a deep political crisis and leaving French President Emmanuel Macron with few options. Details by FRANCE 24 Reporter Claire Paccalin.

items.title: France: Opposition leader Melenchon reacts to PM Lecornu's resignation
items.standfirst: French Prime Minister Sebastien Lecornu tendered the resignation of his government on Monday, less than a day after naming his cabinet. His ministerial picks had provoked consternation amongst ruling alliance allies and opponents, whose support is needed to pass a budget for 2026. The leader of opposition party France Unbowed, Jean-Luc Melenchon, reacted to this announcement. Analysis by FRANCE 24 international affairs editor Philip Turle.
items.content: French Prime Minister Sebastien Lecornu tendered the resignation of his government on Monday, less than a day after naming his cabinet. His ministerial picks had provoked consternation amongst ruling alliance allies and opponents, whose support is needed to pass a budget for 2026. The leader of opposition party France Unbowed, Jean-Luc Melenchon, reacted to this announcement. Analysis by FRANCE 24 international affairs editor Philip Turle.

items.content: Facing criticism from all sides, France's new prime minister Sébastien Lecornu resigned less than 24 hours after naming his government and after less than a month in office, plunging the country into a deep political crisis.(Image credit: Ludovic Marin)

ai_summary: French Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu resigned after less than a month in office.
This marks the third prime minister lost by President Macron in 16 months.
Macron asked Lecornu to attempt to solve the situation by Wednesday.
The resignation adds to France's political and market turmoil.
Lecornu failed to pass spending cuts and tax rises in parliament.

items.title: ICC finds former Sudan militia leader guilty of war crimes in Darfur
items.standfirst: The International Criminal Court in the Hague handed down its first-ever Darfur war crimes conviction, finding Janjaweed leader Ali Kushayb, guilty of atrocities committed more than two decades ago.
items.content: The International Criminal Court in the Hague handed down its first-ever Darfur war crimes conviction, finding Janjaweed leader Ali Kushayb, guilty of atrocities committed more than two decades ago.(Image credit: KOEN VAN WEEL)

items.content: Ali Kushayb led the Janjaweed, a group whose campaign of terror led to hundreds and thousands of deaths.

items.content: The International Criminal Court has found Sudanese militia chief Ali Muhammad Ali Abd-Al-Rahman guilty of war crimes.

items.content: The 27 guilty verdicts are the first handed down by The Hague-based court over war crimes in Sudanese region in 2000s.

items.title: ICC convicts former Sudan militia leader for war crimes in Darfur
items.standfirst: Janjaweed commander Ali Muhammad Ali Abd-al-Rahman, known as Ali Kushayb, found guilty over atrocitiesThe international criminal court has convicted a leader of the Janjaweed militia of playing a leading role in a campaign of atrocities committed in the Sudanese region of Darfur more than 20 years ago.It was the first time the court had convicted a suspect of crimes in Darfur. The court ruled that the atrocities, including mass murders and rapes, were part of a government plan to snuff out a rebellion in the western region of Sudan. Continue reading...
items.content: Janjaweed commander Ali Muhammad Ali Abd-al-Rahman, known as Ali Kushayb, found guilty over atrocitiesThe international criminal court has convicted a leader of the Janjaweed militia of playing a leading role in a campaign of atrocities committed in the Sudanese region of Darfur more than 20 years ago.It was the first time the court had convicted a suspect of crimes in Darfur. The court ruled that the atrocities, including mass murders and rapes, were part of a government plan to snuff out a rebellion in the western region of Sudan. Continue reading...

items.title: Sudanese militia leader convicted of war crimes in Darfur
items.standfirst: The leader of a militia that carried out a series of atrocities and war crimes in the Sudanese region of Darfur has been convicted by the International Criminal Court.
items.content: The leader of a militia that carried out a series of atrocities and war crimes in the Sudanese region of Darfur has been convicted by the International Criminal Court.

items.title: ICC convicts Sudan militia chief in first Darfur war crimes verdict
items.standfirst: The International Criminal Court on Monday convicted Sudanese militia leader Ali Muhammad Ali Abd-Al-Rahman of war crimes and crimes against humanity for brutal attacks in Darfur, marking the court’s first conviction related to the conflict. The Janjaweed chief was found guilty of multiple offenses, including rape, murder and torture committed between August 2003 and April 2004.
items.content: The International Criminal Court on Monday convicted Sudanese militia leader Ali Muhammad Ali Abd-Al-Rahman of war crimes and crimes against humanity for brutal attacks in Darfur, marking the court’s first conviction related to the conflict. The Janjaweed chief was found guilty of multiple offenses, including rape, murder and torture committed between August 2003 and April 2004.

ai_summary: The International Criminal Court convicted Ali Kushayb of war crimes in Darfur.
Kushayb led the Janjaweed militia, responsible for atrocities in Darfur.
The court found Kushayb guilty of atrocities committed over two decades ago.
The conviction is the first for Darfur war crimes by the ICC.
The atrocities included mass murders and rapes, part of a government plan.

items.title: Legal battles begin over Trump's National Guard plans in Portland and Chicago
items.standfirst: Illinois and the city of Chicago are suing the Trump administration over plans to deploy National Guard troops. Meanwhile, a federal judge on Sunday temporarily blocked the White House from sending any National Guard troops to Oregon. CBS News' Jessica Levinson breaks it down.

items.title: Illinois and Chicago sue the Trump administration over National Guard deployment
items.standfirst: The parties are asking a judge to block the Trump administration from federalizing the Illinois National Guard and from sending to Illinois any guard members from other states, including Texas.
items.content: The parties are asking a judge to block the Trump administration from federalizing the Illinois National Guard and from sending to Illinois any guard members from other states, including Texas.(Image credit: Scott Olson)

items.title: Federal judge blocks Trump administration from sending National Guard troops to Portland
items.standfirst: A federal judge late Sunday temporarily blocked the Trump administration from deploying any National Guard units to Oregon at all, after a legal whirlwind that began hours earlier when the president mobilized California troops for Portland after the same judge blocked him from using Oregon's National Guard the day before. Story by Simon Moritz.
items.content: A federal judge late Sunday temporarily blocked the Trump administration from deploying any National Guard units to Oregon at all, after a legal whirlwind that began hours earlier when the president mobilized California troops for Portland after the same judge blocked him from using Oregon's National Guard the day before. Story by Simon Moritz.

items.title: Judge blocks deployment of National Guard to Oregon. And, the Supreme Court's new term

items.content: A judge issues an order to stop Trump's latest attempt to deploy the National Guard to Oregon. And, the Supreme Court opens a new term with justices tackling cases testing presidential power.(Image credit: Spencer Platt)

ai_summary: A judge temporarily blocked Trump from sending National Guard units to Portland.

White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt answered questions on the matter.

items.title: David Ellison says he’s confident Bari Weiss ‘will invigorate CBS News’ as new editor-in-chief
items.standfirst: Paramount said Monday that it has bought the news and commentary website The Free Press and installed its founder, Bari Weiss, as the editor-in-chief of CBS News, saying it believes the country longs for news that is balanced and fact-based. It’s a bold step for the television network of Walter…
items.content: Paramount said Monday that it has bought the news and commentary website The Free Press and installed its founder, Bari Weiss, as the editor-in-chief of CBS News, saying it believes the country longs for news that is balanced and fact-based. It’s a bold step for the television network of Walter…

items.title: CBS News names Bari Weiss as editor-in-chief
items.standfirst: Paramount Skydance also acquired The Free Press, which Weiss co-founded in 2021.
items.content: Bari Weiss, co-founder and CEO of The Free Press, has been appointed CBS News’ editor-in-chief, Paramount announced on Monday. The Free Press will now operate under the company as well. It’s a major move from the company, which merged with Skydance Corp. in August under CEO David Ellison. Under Ellison, the company has made several strategic acquisitions and is reportedly exploring acquiring Warner Bros. Discovery. “This move is part of Paramount’s bigger vision to modernize content and the way it connects – directly and passionately – to audiences around the world,” Ellison said in a statement. “We believe the majority of the country longs for news that is balanced and fact-based, and we want CBS to be their home.” Though she will remain CEO and editor-in-chief of The Free Press, Weiss will report directly to Ellison. The Free Press will maintain its own independent brand and operations, the company said. Weiss and her wife, Nellie Bowles, launched The Free Press in 2021 with Weiss’ sister Suzy. She was previously an opinion writer for The New York Times. Partnering with Paramount, Weiss said, allows The Free Press to expand its audience of 1.5 million. “The values that we’ve hammered out here over the years—journalism based in curiosity and honesty, a culture of healthy disagreement, our shared belief in America’s promise—now have the opportunity to go very, very big,” Weiss wrote in a blog post on The Free Press. Earlier this year, CBS and Paramount settled a $16 million lawsuit with President Donald Trump over a “60 Minutes” interview with then-Vice President Kamala Harris. Paramount then hired an ombudsman to analyze bias in CBS reporting. Weiss said she believes in Ellison and “the entire leadership team who took over Paramount this summer.” She added that they plan to make CBS “the most trusted news organization of the 21st Century.”

items.title: Judge killed in courtroom shooting in Albania
items.standfirst: Man opens fire in Tirana court, killing judge and injuring two other people, and is arrested after fleeing sceneA man on trial opened fire in a courtroom in the Albanian capital, Tirana, killing the judge and injuring two other people, police have said.The judge, Astrit Kalaja, was presiding during a hearing at the court of appeal on Monday when the man opened fire, police said, adding that the shooter was promptly arrested. “The judge was rushed to the hospital, but succumbed to his injuries on the way,” a police statement said. items.title: Rugby world rallies round former England captain Lewis Moody after MND diagnosis
items.standfirst: World Cup winner diagnosed with motor neurone diseaseFundraising page set up by former Leicester teammatesThe rugby world has rallied around the former England captain Lewis Moody, who has revealed he has been diagnosed with motor neurone disease. The 47-year-old 2003 World Cup winner admitted he was having trouble accepting what his diagnosis means for the future but that he intends to stay positive.Among the most decorated forwards to play for England, he earned 71 caps and led his country at the 2011 World Cup in New Zealand, earning the nickname “Mad Dog” as an all-action, hard-hitting flanker. items.title: Former NFL star Mark Sanchez could face six years in jail after being stabbed by 69-year-old
items.standfirst: Quarterback lands felony battery charges on MondayIncident left truck driver with ‘very severe’ injuriesDetectives reviewed video footage of incidentFormer NFL quarterback Mark Sanchez could face jail time after he was charged with felony battery on Monday.The charge is in addition to three others he was handed on Sunday after a violent confrontation earlier in the weekend. Those charges were for battery with injury, public intoxication and unlawful entry of a vehicle during the incident early on Saturday morning that left Sanchez, who has worked as a Fox Sports analyst since his retirement from playing, hospitalized with stab wounds. Continue reading...
items.content: Quarterback lands felony battery charges on MondayIncident left truck driver with ‘very severe’ injuriesDetectives reviewed video footage of incidentFormer NFL quarterback Mark Sanchez could face jail time after he was charged with felony battery on Monday.The charge is in addition to three others he was handed on Sunday after a violent confrontation earlier in the weekend. Those charges were for battery with injury, public intoxication and unlawful entry of a vehicle during the incident early on Saturday morning that left Sanchez, who has worked as a Fox Sports analyst since his retirement from playing, hospitalized with stab wounds. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Former NFL quarterback Mark Sanchez faces felony battery charges.
The charges involve serious bodily injury.
Sanchez could face up to six years in jail.
The charges stem from a violent confrontation.
Sanchez was also charged with battery, public intoxication, and unlawful entry.

clusters.title: Skydiving instructor killed after falling without parachute in Nashville
clusters.neutral_headline: Skydiving Instructor Dies After Falling Without Parachute

items.title: Skydiving instructor killed after falling without parachute in Nashville
items.standfirst: The skydiver fell after becoming separated from his student and safety equipment.
items.content: The skydiver fell after becoming separated from his student and safety equipment.

items.title: US skydiving instructor found dead after evidently falling without parachute
items.standfirst: Authorities say federal aviation agency to investigate incident after also rescuing instructor’s student from treeA 35-year-old skydiving instructor was found dead in a wooded area near Nashville over the weekend after being presumed to have fallen without a parachute, and a student of his was rescued out of a tree, authorities said.Officials added that the pair had become “separated … from a tandem rig” while on the airplane from which they were diving. Continue reading...
items.content: Authorities say federal aviation agency to investigate incident after also rescuing instructor’s student from treeA 35-year-old skydiving instructor was found dead in a wooded area near Nashville over the weekend after being presumed to have fallen without a parachute, and a student of his was rescued out of a tree, authorities said.Officials added that the pair had become “separated … from a tandem rig” while on the airplane from which they were diving. Continue reading...

ai_summary: A skydiving instructor died after falling without a parachute in Nashville.
The instructor became separated from his student and safety equipment.
The student was rescued from a tree.
Authorities are investigating the incident.
The Federal Aviation Agency will investigate the incident.
